title: Next Steps
text: Congratulations on completing the practical! Here‚Äôs how to continue your data science journey.

title: Next Steps
text:
Continue Learning

Free Online Courses
For R:

R for Data Science (2e) - Comprehensive free book by Hadley Wickham
RStudio Primers - Interactive tutorials
Swirl - Learn R programming interactively

For Python:

Python for Everybody - Free course by University of Michigan
Kaggle Learn - Practical micro-courses
DataCamp - First course free, student discounts available

Statistics & Machine Learning:

StatQuest - Excellent YouTube channel for statistics
Introduction to Statistical Learning - Free book with R and Python code
fast.ai - Practical deep learning for coders



University Resources
At Leeds:

Check for data science modules in your program
Attend research seminars and workshops
Join data science student groups
Explore Leeds Institute for Data Analytics (LIDA)

title: Next Steps
text:
Practice with Real Data

Transport-Specific Datasets

UK Department for Transport Statistics
Transport for London Open Data
Propensity to Cycle Tool - Cycling transport data



General Data Sources

data.gov.uk - UK government data
Our World in Data - Global development data
Kaggle Datasets - Thousands of datasets for practice
TidyTuesday - Weekly data challenges

title: Next Steps
text:
Join Communities

Online Communities

RStudio Community - Friendly R forum
r/datascience - Reddit data science community
Stack Overflow - Programming Q&A
Cross Validated - Statistics Q&A



Local Meetups

R User Groups - Find local R meetups
PyData - Python data science meetups
Check Meetup.com for data science events in Leeds

title: Next Steps
text:
Build Your Portfolio

Project Ideas

Analyze local transport patterns using TfL or Leeds data
Recreate published analyses to learn techniques
Participate in Kaggle competitions (start with ‚ÄúGetting Started‚Äù competitions)
Contribute to open source R or Python packages
Create a blog documenting your learning journey



Share Your Work

Create a GitHub profile for your code
Build a portfolio website with Quarto
Write blog posts about what you learn
Share projects on social media (#RStats, #DataScience)

title: Next Steps
text:
Advanced Topics to Explore
Once you‚Äôre comfortable with basics:

Data Science Skills

Version Control: Git and GitHub for collaboration
Reproducible Research: R Markdown, Quarto, Jupyter notebooks
Databases: SQL for working with large datasets
Big Data: Spark, cloud computing (AWS, Google Cloud)



Specialized Topics

Spatial Data Science: Working with geographic data (check out geocompx.org)
Machine Learning: Supervised and unsupervised learning
Deep Learning: Neural networks for complex patterns
Time Series Analysis: For temporal data
Network Analysis: For transport networks and relationships



Transport-Specific Skills

Transport Modeling: Learn about the A/B Street project
Route Planning: OpenTripPlanner, OSRM
GIS: QGIS, ArcGIS for spatial analysis
Transport Data: Working with GTFS, OpenStreetMap

title: Next Steps
text:
Certification & Professional Development

Certifications (Optional)

RStudio Certification
Google Data Analytics Certificate
Microsoft Certified: Azure Data Scientist



Books Worth Reading

R for Data Science - Wickham & Grolemund
The Art of Statistics - David Spiegelhalter
Storytelling with Data - Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic
Python for Data Analysis - Wes McKinney

title: Next Steps
text:
Setting Goals

Short-term (Next Month)

Complete one online course/tutorial
Analyze one dataset of personal interest
Join one online community
Learn one new visualization technique



Medium-term (3-6 Months)

Complete a personal data project
Contribute to an open source project
Attend a meetup or conference
Build a portfolio website



Long-term (1 Year)

Master one data science specialization
Publish a blog post or tutorial
Complete a Kaggle competition
Apply data science in your research/work

title: Next Steps
text:
Final Tips






TipThe Best Way to Learn



Practice, practice, practice! Learning data science is like learning a language‚Äîyou need to use it regularly to improve.








ImportantDon‚Äôt Get Overwhelmed



There‚Äôs a lot to learn, but you don‚Äôt need to learn everything at once. Pick one area, get comfortable, then expand gradually.








NoteStay Curious



The field of data science is constantly evolving. Stay curious, keep learning, and don‚Äôt be afraid to experiment!

title: Next Steps
text:
Get in Touch
Questions or want to share your progress?

Check course materials and updates on this website
Connect with instructors during office hours
Join the course discussion forum
Follow #RStats and #DataScience on social media

Happy coding, and welcome to the world of data science! üöÄüìä

title: GitHub Copilot & AI Tools
text: AI-powered coding assistants can significantly accelerate your data science learning journey. Let‚Äôs explore how to use them effectively!

title: GitHub Copilot & AI Tools
text:
GitHub Copilot
GitHub Copilot is an AI pair programmer that helps you write code faster and with fewer errors.

What is GitHub Copilot?

AI-powered code completion tool
Suggests whole lines or blocks of code as you type
Understands context from your code and comments
Trained on billions of lines of public code



For Students
Good news! Students get free access to GitHub Copilot:

Visit GitHub Education
Apply for the Student Developer Pack
Verify your student status (usually with university email)
Access Copilot for free while you‚Äôre a student



Installing GitHub Copilot
For RStudio:

Currently, Copilot is not natively integrated in RStudio
However, you can use VS Code with R extension as an alternative

For VS Code:

Install Visual Studio Code
Install the GitHub Copilot extension from the marketplace
Sign in with your GitHub account

For Python/Jupyter:

Works seamlessly in VS Code with Python extension
Also available in JupyterLab with Copilot extension

title: GitHub Copilot & AI Tools
text:
Using AI Tools Effectively

Best Practices






TipWriting Good Prompts




Write clear comments describing what you want to do
Use descriptive variable names
Break complex tasks into smaller steps





Example in R

# Load a CSV file of transport data and calculate average trip distance
# Copilot might suggest:
library(tidyverse)
data <- read_csv("transport_data.csv")
avg_distance <- data %>% 
  summarise(mean_distance = mean(trip_distance, na.rm = TRUE))



Example in Python

# Load transport data and visualize trip distribution
# Copilot might suggest:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

data = pd.read_csv("transport_data.csv")
data['trip_distance'].hist(bins=30)
plt.xlabel('Trip Distance')
plt.show()

title: GitHub Copilot & AI Tools
section: Other AI Tools for Data Science
text:
Other AI Tools for Data Science

ChatGPT / Claude

Great for explaining concepts
Helps debug error messages
Suggests approaches to data problems
Tip: Copy error messages and ask for explanations



Stack Overflow & Forums
While not AI per se, these communities are invaluable:

Stack Overflow - Programming Q&A
RStudio Community - R-specific help
r/datascience - Data science discussions

title: GitHub Copilot & AI Tools
text:
Learning with AI

Dos ‚úÖ

Use AI to understand error messages
Ask AI to explain unfamiliar code
Use suggestions to learn new approaches
Verify AI-generated code before using it



Don‚Äôts ‚ùå

Don‚Äôt blindly copy-paste without understanding
Don‚Äôt use AI to do all your work (you won‚Äôt learn!)
Don‚Äôt share sensitive data with AI tools
Don‚Äôt assume AI code is always correct







WarningCritical Thinking Required



AI tools are powerful assistants, but they can make mistakes. Always review and test the code they generate!

title: GitHub Copilot & AI Tools
text:
Practical Exercise
Try this during the session:

Install Copilot (if you haven‚Äôt already)
Write a comment describing a simple data task
See what Copilot suggests
Compare with how you would solve it
Learn from the differences!

title: GitHub Copilot & AI Tools
text:
Resources

GitHub Copilot Documentation
GitHub Student Developer Pack
Effective Copilot Prompts

title: Introduction to Data Science
text: Welcome to this practical introduction to data science! This session is designed for MSc students at the Institute for Transport Studies who are new to data science.

title: Introduction to Data Science
text:
About This Session
In this 3-hour practical, you‚Äôll get hands-on experience with data science concepts and tools. We‚Äôll cover implementations primarily in R and also in Python where applicable.

title: Introduction to Data Science
text:
What You‚Äôll Learn
This session covers:

Prerequisites: Tools and setup you need before getting started
GitHub Copilot & AI Tools: How AI can help you learn and code more effectively
Practical Exercises: Hands-on work with real data science tasks
Next Steps: Resources and pathways for continuing your data science journey

title: Introduction to Data Science
text:
Getting Started
Navigate through the sections using the menu above. We recommend following them in order if you‚Äôre new to data science.
Let‚Äôs begin your data science journey!

title: Prerequisites
text: Before starting this practical session, you‚Äôll need to set up a few essential tools. Don‚Äôt worry‚Äîwe‚Äôll keep this brief!

title: Prerequisites
text:
Required Software

1. R and RStudio
R is a programming language widely used for statistical computing and data science.

Download R from CRAN
Download RStudio Desktop (free) from Posit



2. Python (Optional but Recommended)
Python is another popular language for data science.

Download Python from python.org (version 3.8 or higher)
Or install via Anaconda (includes many data science packages)



3. Git and GitHub Account
Git is version control software, and GitHub is a platform for hosting code.

Download Git from git-scm.com
Create a free GitHub account at github.com

title: Prerequisites
text:
Essential R Packages
Install these R packages by running in RStudio:

# Data manipulation and visualization
install.packages("tidyverse")

# For working with transport data
install.packages("sf")

title: Prerequisites
text:
Essential Python Packages (Optional)
If using Python, install these packages:

pip install pandas numpy matplotlib seaborn

title: Prerequisites
text:
Checking Your Setup

Test R Installation
Open RStudio and run:

# Check R version
R.version.string

# Test tidyverse
library(tidyverse)



Test Python Installation (Optional)
Open a terminal/command prompt and run:

python --version
pip list

title: Prerequisites
text:
Getting Help
If you encounter installation issues:

Check the RStudio Support page
Visit Stack Overflow for troubleshooting
Ask during the session!







TipPro Tip



Don‚Äôt spend too much time troubleshooting installation issues before the session. We can help you during the practical!

title: Practical Exercises
text: Let‚Äôs get hands-on with data science! These exercises will give you practical experience with core data science tasks.

title: Practical Exercises
text:
Exercise 1: Loading and Exploring Data

In R
Let‚Äôs work with a built-in dataset about cars:

# Load tidyverse
library(tidyverse)

# Look at the mtcars dataset
head(mtcars)

# Get basic statistics
summary(mtcars)

# Check the structure
str(mtcars)

Your Task: Explore the dataset and answer: - How many cars are in the dataset? - What variables are included? - What is the average miles per gallon (mpg)?


In Python

import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns

# Load a sample dataset
df = sns.load_dataset('mpg')

# Explore the data
print(df.head())
print(df.describe())
print(df.info())

title: Practical Exercises
text:
Exercise 2: Data Visualization

Visualizing in R
Create a simple plot to understand the relationship between variables:

library(ggplot2)

# Scatter plot: mpg vs weight
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  labs(title = "Fuel Efficiency vs Car Weight",
       x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
       y = "Miles per Gallon") +
  theme_minimal()

Your Task: - Create the plot above - What pattern do you observe? - Try changing the x variable to hp (horsepower)


Visualizing in Python

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Load data
df = sns.load_dataset('mpg')

# Create scatter plot
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
sns.scatterplot(data=df, x='weight', y='mpg')
plt.title('Fuel Efficiency vs Car Weight')
plt.xlabel('Weight')
plt.ylabel('Miles per Gallon')
plt.show()

title: Practical Exercises
text:
Exercise 3: Data Manipulation

Filtering and Summarizing in R

library(tidyverse)

# Filter cars with good fuel efficiency (mpg > 20)
efficient_cars <- mtcars %>%
  filter(mpg > 20)

# Calculate average mpg by cylinder count
mpg_by_cyl <- mtcars %>%
  group_by(cyl) %>%
  summarise(
    avg_mpg = mean(mpg),
    count = n()
  )

print(mpg_by_cyl)

Your Task: - How many cars have mpg > 20? - Which cylinder count has the best average fuel efficiency? - Filter for cars with automatic transmission (am == 0)


Filtering in Python

import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns

df = sns.load_dataset('mpg')

# Filter cars from the USA
usa_cars = df[df['origin'] == 'usa']

# Group by year and calculate average mpg
mpg_by_year = df.groupby('model_year')['mpg'].mean()

print(mpg_by_year)

title: Practical Exercises
text:
Exercise 4: Working with Transport Data

Creating Simple Transport Analysis in R

library(tidyverse)

# Create a simple trip dataset
trips <- data.frame(
  trip_id = 1:10,
  distance_km = c(5.2, 3.1, 7.8, 2.5, 15.3, 4.2, 6.7, 8.9, 3.4, 5.8),
  mode = c("bus", "walk", "car", "walk", "train", "bus", "car", "bike", "walk", "bus"),
  duration_min = c(25, 15, 20, 10, 45, 20, 18, 30, 12, 22)
)

# Calculate average speed by mode
trip_summary <- trips %>%
  mutate(speed_kmh = (distance_km / duration_min) * 60) %>%
  group_by(mode) %>%
  summarise(
    avg_speed = mean(speed_kmh),
    avg_distance = mean(distance_km),
    count = n()
  )

print(trip_summary)

Your Task: - Which transport mode has the highest average speed? - Calculate the total distance traveled across all trips - Create a bar plot showing trip counts by mode


Visualization

# Create a bar plot of trips by mode
ggplot(trips, aes(x = mode)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "steelblue") +
  labs(title = "Number of Trips by Transport Mode",
       x = "Transport Mode",
       y = "Number of Trips") +
  theme_minimal()

title: Practical Exercises
text:
Bonus Challenge
If you finish early, try this:

Find a real dataset online (e.g., from data.gov.uk or Our World in Data)
Load it into R or Python
Create 3 visualizations that tell a story about the data
Share your findings with the group!

title: Practical Exercises
text:
Common Issues & Solutions






NoteError: Package not found



Make sure you‚Äôve installed the package first:
install.packages("package_name")








NoteError: Object not found



Check that you‚Äôve run all previous code chunks in order. Variables from earlier chunks need to be created first!








TipGetting Stuck?




Check the documentation: ?function_name in R
Use AI tools like Copilot or ChatGPT
Ask your neighbor or the instructor!

title: Practical Exercises
text:
Key Takeaways
After completing these exercises, you should be able to:
‚úÖ Load and explore datasets
‚úÖ Create basic visualizations
‚úÖ Filter and summarize data
‚úÖ Calculate derived variables
‚úÖ Understand transport data structures
